title: An Unexpected Case of Otosclerosis
chief_complaint: I've noticed my hearing going down gradually over the last year, especially after I had a bad virus and ear infections. I can hear people talking, but I can't always understand what they are saying, and my wife keeps telling me the TV is too loud.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual onset over the past year.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating (reports hearing better on some days); progressive.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant bilateral tinnitus (3 years), occasional feeling of being 'off-balance'.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty understanding speech, need for increased TV volume.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking explanation for hearing loss; initially attributed it to a virus.

history.present_illness: Patient reports decreased hearing bilaterally over the past year, attributed to a virus and otitis media. Prior test showed 20 dB HL drop. Reports hearing vs. understanding difficulties.
history.otologic_history: Recent bilateral ear infections reported by patient. Occasional imbalance.
history.noise_exposure_history: Forklift operator in automobile factory and airport for >10 years with limited hearing protection.
history.prior_management: None specified other than a prior hearing check.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetric moderate rising to mild mixed hearing loss (250-3000 Hz), sloping to moderate conductive loss at 4000 Hz, and rising to mild loss at 6-8 kHz. Notable Carhart notch (bone conduction depression) at 2000 Hz.

numeric_results.Bone Conduction: Carhart notch present at 2000 Hz (approx 35 dB HL)
numeric_results.Air-Bone Gap: Significant gaps present in low frequencies and at 4000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Recognition Thresholds (SRT) align with pure tone averages. Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent acoustic reflexes at 500-4000 Hz for both ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation.

history.present_illness: Referral following audiological evaluation suggesting otosclerosis.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Microscopic otoscopy revealed bilateral Schwartze signs (reddish hue on promontory). CT scan showed no temporal bone abnormalities but questionable oval window otosclerosis.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, symmetric mixed hearing loss. While tympanometry is normal (Type A), acoustic reflexes are absent, and a distinct Carhart notch is visible at 2000 Hz in bone conduction thresholds. Speech understanding remains excellent when volume is sufficient. These findings, combined with the specific configuration of the air-bone gaps, are classic audiological indicators of otosclerosis.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a 'mixed' hearing loss, meaning there is a problem with how sound travels through the middle ear bones, in addition to some inner ear wear.
The specific pattern we see (a dip in the bone conduction hearing at 2000 Hz and absent reflexes) strongly suggests a condition called otosclerosis, where the stirrup bone gets stuck.
Even though you have a history of noise exposure, the primary cause of your current difficulty appears to be this middle ear condition.
We are referring you to an otologist (ear specialist) to discuss medical options, which may include surgery to fix the middle ear bone or hearing aids.
Given your noise exposure history, you should continue to wear hearing protection at work to prevent further damage to the inner ear.
notes_for_actor: You are a 37-year-old African American male.
You believe your hearing loss was caused by a 'virus' or ear infections you had recently.
You are frustrated because you can hear people talking, but the words aren't clear ('I hear but don't understand').
You have had ringing in your ears (tinnitus) for 3 years.
You feel a bit off-balance sometimes.
You are open to surgery if it will fix the problem, as you perceive the left ear to be worse.
